content.raw:
I think the only thing stopping this from getting merged is the lack of docs. If you add mentions of OpenPMD support to the following places, following the descriptions for other supported output formats, that would be sufficient:

* http://yt-project.org/docs/dev/examining/index.html
* http://yt-project.org/docs/dev/reference/code_support.html

The documentation is located in the `doc/source` folder at the root of the yt repository. If you need a hand with sphinx or RST I'm happy to help out.

Ping @atmyers to review this. Since you wrote a particle frontend relatively recently and even helped out a bit with the chunking strategy used here, it would be great if you could look over this pull request.
content.html:
I think the only thing stopping this from getting merged is the lack of docs. If you add mentions of OpenPMD support to the following places, following the descriptions for other supported output formats, that would be sufficient:

  • http://yt-project.org/docs/dev/examining/index.html
  • http://yt-project.org/docs/dev/reference/code_support.html

The documentation is located in the doc/source folder at the root of the yt repository. If you need a hand with sphinx or RST I'm happy to help out.

Ping Andrew Myers to review this. Since you wrote a particle frontend relatively recently and even helped out a bit with the chunking strategy used here, it would be great if you could look over this pull request.

content.raw:
Thanks for adding docs!

Once @atmyers or someone else looks this over I think we're ready to merge.
content.html:
Thanks for adding docs!

Once Andrew Myers or someone else looks this over I think we're ready to merge.

content.raw:
This should be using the on-demand import machinery, h5py isn't a hard dependency (although many frontends use it and we install it by default in the install script).

You're actually using the on-demand import h5py already in this pull request in `data_structures.py`.
content.html:
This should be using the on-demand import machinery, h5py isn't a hard dependency (although many frontends use it and we install it by default in the install script).

You're actually using the on-demand import h5py already in this pull request in data_structures.py.

content.raw:
This was done somewhat deliberately. Lines 147 and 188 check for a `h5.Dataset` which the on-demand import does not have.
Thinking about it, a solution should be fairly simple. Either check for `not h5.Group` or I'll hack together a property `h5py_imports.Dataset`.
content.html: This was done somewhat deliberately. Lines 147 and 188 check for a h5.Dataset which the on-demand import does not have. Thinking about it, a solution should be fairly simple. Either check for not h5.Group or I'll hack together a property h5py_imports.Dataset.

content.raw: Yup, adding a wrapper for h5py.Dataset to the on-demand importer is the way to go.
content.html: Yup, adding a wrapper for h5py.Dataset to the on-demand importer is the way to go.

content.raw: It looks like the last push introduced some test failures on python3.5.
content.html: It looks like the last push introduced some test failures on python3.5.

That will create a new file if args[0] doesn't exist, it will also pass if file is empty. Could you change it to:

try:
    f = h5.File(args[0], 'r')
except (IOError, OSError):
    return False

?

content.raw:
I don't know how often openPMD output changes, but could you operate on versions instead of raw strings here? Something like:

```
#!python
from distutils.version import LooseVersion

min_supported_version = LooseVersion("1.0.0")
max_supported_version = LooseVersion("1.0.1")
my_version = LooseVersion(f.attrs["openPMD"].decode())

return min_supported_version <= my_version <= max_supported_version
```
content.html:
I don't know how often openPMD output changes, but could you operate on versions instead of raw strings here? Something like:

from distutils.version import LooseVersion

min_supported_version = LooseVersion("1.0.0")
max_supported_version = LooseVersion("1.0.1")
my_version = LooseVersion(f.attrs["openPMD"].decode())

return min_supported_version <= my_version <= max_supported_version

content.raw: What kind of exception are you trying to catch here?
content.html: What kind of exception are you trying to catch here?

content.raw: Same as above: what kind of exception?
content.html: Same as above: what kind of exception?

content.raw: Could update API docs too? Specifically frontend section in `doc/source/reference/api/api.rst`. Otherwise all those excellent docstrings that you  wrote won't be available.
content.html: Could update API docs too? Specifically frontend section in doc/source/reference/api/api.rst. Otherwise all those excellent docstrings that you wrote won't be available.

content.raw: Thanks so much for your dogged persistence on this! I think we're really close to merging this.
content.html: Thanks so much for your dogged persistence on this! I think we're really close to merging this.

content.raw: The chunking/io code looks great to me. I think this is a very high-quality submission - tests, docs, clear and documented code. I think it's totally ready to merge in.
content.html: The chunking/io code looks great to me. I think this is a very high-quality submission - tests, docs, clear and documented code. I think it's totally ready to merge in.

content.raw: Thank you very much for your contribution. Congratulations! :fireworks:
content.html: Thank you very much for your contribution. Congratulations!

description:
This PR creates a new frontend for the open Particle Mesh Data standard. http://www.openpmd.org/#/start https://github.com/openPMD/openPMD-standard/blob/upcoming-1.0.1/STANDARD.md

The current version covers large parts of the standard. 1D/2D/3D cartesian datasets (with one iteration per file) that contain particles and/or meshes in one bounding region are supported. We do not fully verify standard-compliance, we expect the data to be 1.0.x. We do check for one kwarg ("open_pmd_virtual_gridsize") to allow the user to easily change chunking behaviour if needed. We do also expect h5py to be present, we import it directly at one point (maybe make it a required dependency for yt?)

The current code works with both Python 2 and 3. Test data is from our github https://github.com/openPMD/openPMD-example-datasets/commit/2bb92f7d5fc96ec5259cfcf036fea67ccc32fe42 (example-2d.tar.gz and example-3d.tar.gz). Documentation has been written for the essential parts of code.
